text: Blackie's brothers hello my needle drops
Anthony Fantan oh here and it's time for
an album review the Black Keys are a
blues rock duo from Akron Ohio and this
is their sixth album the title is
brothers at six albums and just about
any band is going to be in an
interesting place and that's no less
true for the Black Keys in 2008 the band
put out a tight colorful little album
called attack and release the Danger
Mouse produced LP removed some of the
gritty wandering elements of the Bands
music and replaced them with some studio
Sheen and extra instrumentation brothers
which may excite some fans is return to
the basics the drums and guitar
foundation that made the Black Keys
early work so great plus the Black Keys
have taken to producing their own music
once again but still brought on Danger
Mouse to produce the single tighten up
which is arguably one of the best tracks
on the LP so even though brothers may be
somewhat of a return to the Black Keys
earlier work it doesn't mean the bad
ignores and abandons everything that
they've learned up into this point for
example whether it's an instrument or an
effect or a studio trick the band makes
sure to put a signature sound into each
track making it easy to separate one
song from another for example she's long
gone has some really unique guitar squak
effects also too afraid to love you has
a beautiful harpsichord that really
colors the background of the song the
opener everlasting light which I
absolutely love has some great falsetto
vocals brought to us by Dan Auerbach and
the track black mud is a short little
instrumental brothers is a little more
brave in terms of length to adding
almost 20 more minutes than its
predecessor and several more tracks to
over all the songs are longer and take a
bit more time to build and emphasize
groove and atmosphere rather than making
sure you hear the hook right off the bat
the attitude of brothers is something to
make note of - maybe it took this new LP
to see it but the passion on brothers
makes attack and release
look as if the Black Keys are playing
karaoke over their own songs I find the
emotion on this new LP to be really open
authentic and relatable maybe overall
it's not as immediate as attack and
release but still the dirty blues based
rock that made this band popular is back
with a few occasional John's into the
world of soul music though I do commend
the Black Keys for doing what they've
always done better than ever
arguably there's still not enough
stylistic separation between this LP and
their earlier work for me to say that
this is the greatest album in the world
plus I think the largest disappointment
on this entire album which is always a
downer for me personally is when you
have a cover on the album and the cover
on brothers being the Jerry Butler song
never going to give you up you have a
cover on brothers which is better than
every other original song on the album
years from now will we look to brothers
or will we look to an LP like rubber
factory and say to ourselves yeah that's
the Black Keys best album or do you
think it'll be something that the band
will release after this LP so what I
guess I'm getting at is that I like this
LP I like it more than attack and
release and I like it more than magic
potion too but I still think LPS like
rubber factory and thickfreakness take
the cake I'm feeling a strong 6 to a
light 7 on this most likely a light 7
but if you're into the Black Keys and
you've heard this LP what do you think
about it do you love it
do you hate it and how do you think it
compares to the Bands earlier work 6
albums in there's quite a bit to compare
this to anthony Fantana The Black Keys
brothers forever
[Music]
